review_title: Chaotic, low-budget with a decent story.
review_detailed_main:
Lately I've been seeing more and more sci-fi movies, which are actually a romantic dramas with a pretty standard Hollywoodish script. The only difference is, that these dramas are set in a sci-fi setting. Either in space, or far away in the future. In this movie, they had to pick. It was either going to be a pretty good sci-fi story, or a cheesy romance, exploited many times in Sci- Fi, but rarely touched in romantic movies. Well, they failed to decide so it turned out to be half decent Sci-fi plus half decent romantic story. And we all know that having two halves of different bills is not the same as having a single hundred-dollar bill.

The story is not new, but still it could be a very pleasant sci-fi. It unfolded so quickly, that if we remove the romantic part, it could pass for a trailer. Music score was heavily influenced by Blade Runner, acting was pretty bad (Even John Cusack could not save it). Camera guy was still learning, CGI's were decent.

They tried creating a huge movie with a dramatic story, set between among the stars. But to create such big thing, you need a lot of money. Obviously they did not have them and now it looks like a low- budget version of Star Gate. If they tried creating a 7-8 series out of this script, it could have had a huge success.

C. was a producer , but no..., is it a low budget - yes it is . then I had to see other titles by R.K. It seems like the movie was made between few beers ,some parts are good, and then there is a shocker,or maybe the bar got closed.

I absolutely LOVE John Cusack, so I'm gonna do myself a favor, tell myself he lost a bet, do my damn best to save others from wasting precious time on this sadness. I don't know what I hated most about this... "movie"... but I'm going with a plea to the entire movie making industry.. PLEASE!! Please don't give either of those young will-never-be actors another shot at stealing time from other human beings EVER again. And whatever the bet John lost... I'm sure he's learned his lesson.
How this spectacularly horrible movie has even a 4.2 rating is confounding; not one single redeeming facet to this movie at all.

I tend to trust "some" imdb scores. But lately this has proven wrong.

So, now i try movies in the mid-range. When i watched this it was sill passing 5 stars. Now i can agree with other reviewers that complain about tons of 9-star ratings with no review.

The story was dull. Don't get me wrong. I like post-apocalyptic themes, and technology stuff. However, i want a least a vague sense of plausibility when tackling the theme.

This movie tries to go into Terminator territory. AI gone crazy, and deciding to exterminate humans. That's just the introduction, there is no explanation not development on that. You have to witness the AI kill humankind and then skip forward 97 years. (why not 100?).

And then, the story revolves around 2 novice actors. Novice as in "they can't act". It is awful. I've seen best acting in street comedy. The "old" actors (Carmen Argenziano and John Cusack) and like they are not convinced. . I can pass that up. Then there is the FX. It is BAD. I don't require great FX for a good movie, but c'mon. At least try. Most current games look more realistic.

But then i return to the story. And that i cannot forgive. It is boring. The lines are tedious and repetitive. You could guess what was going to happen or was going to be said.

I won't spoil the movie. But it keeps on going. It is boring, dull, and tiring. Other movies, with less money, unknown actors, had brilliant scripts, and kept me engaged. I feel this movie will bore you as it bored me, so PLEASE .... Skip it. You can go watch Terminator, and even if you don't really like it, you will be more entertain with the action.

I barely know where to start with this mess.

Here's my issues, to add to all the others (obviously there's duplicates, but I'm not reading all the other reviews). "Physical" inconsistencies: So let me get this straight... There's an AI that controls the entire planet, but it can't track down an interstellar spaceship sitting on the surface of the planet? Somehow humans were able to construct interstellar ships without the AI knowing? Somehow they launched off the planet in the past, but the AI couldn't track them, or know where they left from? 100 years after the destruction after the vast majority of humans: The ones that still exist somehow still have power to light flashlights? Batteries in a Polaroid camera still hold a charge? Electronic devices that still function? Someone has brand new looking Ø1" rope? The AI can't track the remaining humans by their campfires? The AI doesn't have thermal imaging? Clothes are still "normal" looking? The bow and arrows, which serve no purpose in the plot line other than to insert a character that looks like Katniss Everdeen into the story, look like they were just purchased from Cabelas? Some unused buildings haven't been totally overgrown by nature and still look pristine on the inside even though windows are open for the past 100 years. People and their clothes are still "clean" with pearly white teeth?

This list is endless....

I won't bother talking about the acting. Others have pretty much covered that. It suffices to say that it's terrible.

Story sucks and just looks like it's trying to set up round 2.

I blame Netflix for this recommendation.
Such a bad movie, the main actors are dreadful I think the male actor may have downs, definitely can't act.

review_title: Not, perhaps, as bad as the 11+ pages state?
review_detailed_main:
Aw, Gods! Am I gonna love this! ;) OK! Here goes! There's about 11+ pages of people pouring fire and brimstone over this movie. So... Let's do the easy stuff first.

Yes, CGI is often horrible. There's no matching the background lighting and colors. Sometimes I've seen a lot worse and from, for instance, SYFY.

Acting could have been better. Eileen Grubba isn't too bad as Andrew's mother. And, all likenesses to a certain Katniss Everdeen aside, Jeannine Wacker has potential. Julian Schaffner should, however, attend acting classes more often, though. Being kewt just isn't enough these days. Sorry, kiddo!

Some (most) people complain about John Cusak's and Carmen Argenziano's acting (from bad to worse and WTF) and the fact that there's a city with bright lights on in skyscrapers. Some 97 years after Armageddon.

How 'bout this! Go back to about 4:40 into the movie and hear Kronos say "I will feel you. Do not be afraid" and ponder what that implies. If you still don't get it, fast forward to about 9:20 and watch Elias moving about. Still no response? Well, fast forward again to 36:13 and listen to what Calia says.

Cusak's and Argenziano's acting isn't half bad considering the above. It's like they have no real choice. Still don't get it? Repeat ad nauseum! But, hey, this isn't a movie with outstanding character portraits. It's Sci-Fi!

Yes, there are similarities to Terminator. Of course there are. And I'm not talking about possible dupes of robots. I mean, if an AI reaches singularity and takes over, what would you expect? Humans are, after all, something to be... dealt with. Perhaps Kronos did the right thing after all?

About a year ago, on SciFi-movies.com, the movie "Aurora" popped up. A full length feature by Robert Kouba, a young Swiss short film maker. A bit of investigation gave that crowd funded "Aurora" had been canceled and, thusly, I wrote to Scifi-movies and had it removed. I thought Kouba would be out of the picture. Check out the trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XcohH3YG4tM

As you can see from this trailer, it's "Singularity"! So, "Aurora" lived on and became "Singularity". Finally.

Have I seen better movies? Of course I have! Have I seen worse? No doubt about that! So, I actually do rate this a 5 despite all the deficiencies.

Clear your mind and watch it!

review_title: Words Cannot describe how bad this movie is.
review_detailed_main: Worst of everything - bad acting, horrible script, worst directing ever ... there is nothing in this movie that is redeemable. Wow just wow ... pathetic.

review_title: Singularity is a black hole; and you wish someone would have dropped this film down one.
review_detailed_main: Numerous plotholes. Gigantic, Buick-sucking plotholes. Scene: in the near future, artificial intelligence is invented. It quickly wipes out humanity. Okay then we telescope time 97 years later. Humanity is down to a few scattered survivors... Roughing it in the wilderness with perfect hair, manscaped beards, clean and fashionable clothing in immaculate shape. With supplies running out, oh wait, where did that 1980's Polaroid instamatic camera come from? Why does its batteries work? Or why does it have film in it?!? Special effects I was okay with for a low budget flick. Acting was... passable for a low budget. The script however, oh God, the script. What a mess. They tried to have a twist ending, but it doesn't make sense with anything else. It's a crying shame that other movies are not green lit that stand the chance of being decent stories. This one should have been flushed.

This seems like a movie for kids. Like an after school special. I'm talking 8 to 15 years old

There is no profanity, sex or nudity. There is violence. But no gore or torture.

Adults could watch it with children. But I don't think adults would want to watch it alone.

review_title: It was so bad it made me angry
This may be the worst movie I have ever seen
review_detailed_main: Story, acting, writing, direction...awful. This may be the worst movie I have ever seen. Plan 9 was better. I kid you not. I fell asleep after 5 minutes, woke up...fast forwarded through it, I simply could not take it. Cusak must have needed a mortgage payment.
I watched the whole thing wondering if it was really this bad the whole time? Yeah, it was and is.

Boring and slow. No real payoff for watching. Main actress was good.

review_title: Calm the hate, and see this for what it is, a first film by students, that lucked out getting a couple big name cameos
review_detailed_main:
I'll say for starters, this is not a great film, not when compared to actual studio productions. What it feels like is a home project, for the two main leads or the director, as either university study, or just a hobby that grew into a full length film, so don't expect studio quality or the kind of continuity tracking or set design that would go along with this. There are other signs of unexpected growth with jerky plot motion, and filler dialogue by narration. All the scenes with Cusack appear to have been done over a single day shoot, in a darkened hotel room, and for the most part are repeated snap shots of him staring into space, later filled with graphics, done with a regrettable flatness; though it may be he's only done this as a favour.. Carmen feels more involved with the project. The plot and dialogue are a bit sketchy for them to work with though, think terminator universe, with hunger games mockingbird characters, and you won't be far off.

However it's not all terrible, you can tell a lot of work has gone into it, and the graphic scenes could be very well done at times. The actors are young and inexperienced, but I thought the female lead at least kept it alive from an emotional stand point.

If you're looking for a punt.. just keep expectation low. I don't mind that I've seen it, and it may be just a long way round to getting the attention of a studio to make the second part fully, and although I don't get why it was released as a film rather than handed in at end of term, you may find odd moments it doesn't suck, like I did.

Even the cool battlemechs can't pull this one out of being a smoldering dungpile. The two leads were obviously cast because they looked good not because they had even a sliver of talent. And to compound it they give the female lead, who delivers her lines with the skill a second grade school play flower, voice-over responsibility. And yes, the results are painful to listen to. Oh, John Cusack stops in to pick up a paycheck, not act, as well. Watching this makes The 100 feel like a high concept scifi masterpiece.

review_title: Epic bad acting over re-hashed scifi plot
review_detailed_main: Every actor in this was the worst at their craft, including John Cusack who texted-in, didn't even bother to phone-in, his wooden silly performance. The two younger actors can maybe plead inexperience and bad direction. The plot is just a mish-mash ripoff of bits of Terminator and Matrix and every other "computers rule the world" scifi - all done better than this. It had a few decent effects so I gave it a 2, but really NOT worth a watch.
This has a 93% on netflix. It's more like a 3/10, maybe, but I wouldn't have watched it if it had an honest review.

If the writer had given his plot to a sci/fi writer and a solid producer, who would in turn get a decent budget, director and actors (Good CGI), then maybe this could have been a decent movie. Instead it's a one man ego fest. I love the idea of AI going wrong, because within the last year we were introduced to the first true AI (AlphaZero). The timeline of this plot foundation fits it , just as ex machina's plot foundation of the world's greatest search engine company creating the first AI (Google created AlphaZero) With AlphaZero and Space Force converging at the same time, I see exciting and perhaps frightening things ahead. Hollywood needs to come up with some fresh ideas regarding AI to keep up.

Ridiculous, convoluted story that made little sense, with elements ripped off from Terminator, Walking Dead, The Road, and a few B-grade sci-fi movies. And John Cusack...well, he must have needed the money. Maybe someday he'll be in something respectable again.

review_title: 5 cent acting and directing, good CGI.
review_detailed_main:
You can't like any of the characters. All the actors talk slow and confused, or panicky with clearly fake intention. All the lines are cliche.

The CGI robot in the beginning is modelled very well except for a fixed happy grin in a scene where it's at home. This is alarming to the viewer but there's no "pick up" on it. There are actors in the scene but they are purposefully acting in an unimportant way, so you don't care, which makes the whole scene confusing and pointless.

None of the leads act according to the scenes. The master robot builder acts in a mysterious way when talking to his "creation". In reality if he really put work into it - more than any other person alive - he would know everything in an "of course" manner, not be in a wandering god delusion.

The other leads act in a similar wandering god delusion or a panic. Then deliver cliche lines.

review_title: Check In: Singularity (2017) To: Ross Little,
review_detailed_main: Great review. The only thing you missed was how the hell John Cusack was able to watch the progress? Where are the cameras??

All in all it lies with Robert Kouba the writer and director you may say, but no, it lies with the flamin' eejuts who supplied the money to make it. I'd love to be able to put some of the dialogue in and some observations but dear reader you would not believe. Watch it stoned is all I'll say, oh go on I'll give you one bit of dialogue, "wild berries had no flavour anymore".
I will never get back that 90 minutes. Terrible effects. Weak script. Actors way too clean. Over lite in the interiors sets and ext night scenes.

I don't want anyone to make the same mistake I did so I'm adding my 2* rating with the hope it prevents even one person from clicking the play button instead of, I don't know, anything else.

Cusack's entire appearance in the film was spent mugging and uttering nonsensical dialogue. The young leads cannot act whatsoever and their dialogue was juvenile and absolute trash. Honestly, the plot that the film tried to accomplish, and failed miserably, could be fascinating and I am hoping a movie can be made, in more skilled hands, although it wouldn't take much skill to make a film better than this. I do agree with reviewers who stated the positive ratings on this film were most certainly not genuine. No one with a modicum of intelligence and taste would find this film anything other than garbage.

It's like a knock off Hunger Games, Maze Runner, Eagle Eye, and Terminator, except 1000 times worse......what was John Cusack thinking?!?! He was acting more like Nicholas Cage, *shudders*. Not even laughably bad, just painfully bad. If you see an amazing trailer of some obscure movie you've never heard of, chances are the actual film is horrible....this movie proves that point.
The story is ok, but the acting is terrible and the characters look like they just got back from the mall. Not very post apocalyptic.

review_title: Neither awful nor good... had promise but borrowed ideas, missed a script writer
review_detailed_main:
Cross between hunger games, robot jox and i-robot to name a few. It looks good, patches of bad cgi but to be honest it's forgivable. The music is slick and good. The script is muddled, babble and nonsense, especially from the two young actors. I actually wanted John Cusack in the film more. The lines were a little cringeworthy in places e.g. "worst" was spoken.

Overall, a case of glitz over substance, neither awful nor good. Shame as it reminded me of 80's films where bad was actually good though.

A B-movie rehash of Terminator Salvation (with a dash of The Matrix), except the android falls in love, and Helena Bonham Carter's SkyNet is replaced with a deranged Elon Musk played by John Cusack.

The production values aren't bad for a B-movie, but the very, very shallow story offers nothing new. I think some of the problem is that the movie is barely an hour an a half long, so it ends up feeling rushed; with all the wasted scenes of Cusack watching from afar, it ends up feeling like an over-long short film instead of a feature-length story.

I guess there's a bit of a surprise/twist ending, but when you see it you'll just think "Uh, OK."

There were also oddities in the writing that broke immersion. For example:

The special effects actually didn't seem so bad to me... But everything else was absolutely horrible. I couldn't even make it through the first half hour it was so bad, and none of it made any sense whatsoever. I don't understand why this movie even exists.
Pretty much what everyone else said, poorly acted, no authenticity or originality
The horrible acting and huge plot holes in this movie make it almost unwatchable. Super disappointed in this movie. It had such an interesting premise, but it fell flat.
It's only an hour and a half... wow, that was bad.

Really? Again?

Btw... The Matrix isn't original either... there's old black & white " Colossus ", episodes of Star Trek , I, Robot, Terminator, and I'm sure plenty of others.

I think we get not to put a supercomputer in charge of us without a disconnect... I hope those in the government have this concept drilled into them by now & not to do this on any level.

review_title: Wow this is such a bad movie.
review_detailed_main:
I wanted to give this movie 1/10. But I have to admit that it's not as bad as Plan 9 From Outer Space, or Manos The Hands of Fate. The special effects look better than paper mache and string. The background music is passable. The acting is slightly better than your average high school drama club. But all of this is overshadowed by the sheer stupidity of the plot and the dialog. I've seen some awful post-apocalyptic movies, from Logan's Run to Wall-E. Singularity blows them all away. It's terrible.

It seems that whoever wrote this screenplay lacks the ability to predict what real people would do or say in a given situation. Scene after scene, the characters act in ways that make no sense and say things that no sane person would ever say. But at least they speak in sentences rather than gibberish. And I can understand the actors' accents. So kudos for that.
It was so bad we could not make it through 40 minutes.

review_title: A study guide in "How NOT To"
review_detailed_main: This production is an interesting premise in search of a bigger budget, better writing, better direction, better acting, better effects.....you get the idea. The basic concept is not new - think "Skynet" in the "Terminator" series - but the twist is worth exploring. Unfortunately it's not executed very well here. However this is a good movie to watch and make notes on what not to do when making a movie.

When making a direct-to-vdeo/streaming B movie with a tired premise, there are decisions a director can make to elevate a bad film.

Here some suggestions :

* MECHS! Mecha are instantly attractive to audiences. Play that up. Exploit the mechs. It's a great angle. Singularity doesn't have enough mechs.

* GORE! Gore in a bad film automatically makes it more enjoyable. Heck, even memorable. Singularity doesn't have any gore : (

* SCORE! The featured score is boring and serviceable. Why not make your low budget film stand out with a more avant-garde score? IE: Decoder (1984)

With its lousy script that didn't give the actors much to do, this film was doomed, and nothing was done to 'punch it up'. I never thought I'd see John Cusack in a worse film after 2012. I was wrong. Singularity is that film. At least 2012 was unintentionally hilarious.

Some of the locations and shots are genuinely beautiful. Some of the special effects shots even look great. This could have made a very good video game. A good film? Definitely not.
If you were to take Terminator, Hunger Games, Darryl Dixon's crossbow, add a dash of Ear Games, and add some Sauron and his magic eye and put in a blender you would end up with this movie - CRAP!

review_title: It's as if someone tried to turn his visual effects reel into a feature film
review_detailed_main:
This movie is inept on almost every level--except one.

The story is a nonsensical hash of ideas lifted from other, better movies. The acting and direction are terrible. The dialogue is laughable.

The only thing about it that's any good is the visual effects. Some of them are quite cool.

I can see how a movie this bad gets made. There's one person credited with the script, directing and even the editing of the film. One Robert Goupa. So you can see how one person might become invested in this idea and lose sight of how awful it is.

What's s hard to believe that anyone would finance such an obviously terrible script. I can only guess that the people who put money into it must have believed that the effects would somehow carry the day.

Massive potential and none of it taken. More holes in the story than Swiss cheese, dreadful acting (with possible exception of John Cusack who gave an average performance). Cinematography, special effects and script are all just beyond poor.
